variant.question: At a tropical airfield during the rainy season, heavy rain showers often cause the runways to be very wet. Which of the following landing techniques should be used when landing on these runways?

options.text: The pilot should maintain normal approach and landing technique but use a slower approach and landing speed compared to dry runway operations.
Positive landings with prompt full application of all retardation devices and maximum brake/autobrake with anti-skid.
Landings should be made with light touchdowns, maximum air brake and reverse thrust but minimum anti-skid braking.
Use of reverse thrust should be kept to a minimum to avoid water spray and ingestion; anti-skid braking should be applied slowly to avoid hydroplaning.

variant.question: How do auto brakes affect the landing distance in comparison to manual braking?

options.text: Decrease landing distance by maintaining maximum autobrakes.
Decrease landing distance by maintaining selected autobrakes.
Increase landing distance by maintaining maximum autobrakes.
Increase landing distance by maintaining selected autobrakes.

variant.question: Which statement regarding the influence of a runway down-slope is correct for a balanced take-off? Down-slope:

options.text: reduces V1 and reduces take-off distance required (TODR).
increases V1 and reduces the accelerate stop distance required (ASDR).
reduces V1 and increases the accelerate stop distance required (ASDR).
increases V1 and increases the take-off distance required (TODR).

variant.question:
Which of the following items can limit the Maximum Permissible Landing Mass for a Quick Turnaround?

1\. Aerodrome pressure altitude   
2\. Aerodrome temperature   
3\. Air conditioning packs ON/OFF   
4\. Flap setting   
5\. Runway slope   
6\. Use of reverse thrust   
7\. Wind component

You are flying to a destination with limited fuel services and a short runway. To minimise fuel uplift requirements at the destination you plan to land with the maximum amount of fuel possible. What factor might limit your landing mass?

options.text: High OAT as it leads to a higher groundspeed.
Low OAT as it leads to a lower groundspeed.
A runway upslope as it increases landing distance.
A runway downslope as it leads to a reduced landing distance.

variant.question: A crew is planning their departure from Mykonos (Greece), expecting a take-off towards the sea, from a short field runway. Which of these is most likely to be the limiting take-off mass?

options.text: Climb limited take-off mass.
Field-length limited take-off mass.
Tyre limited take-off mass.
Obstacle limited take-off mass.

variant.question:
In case of landing on a flooded runway and in stormy conditions you will:

1\. increase your approach speed,   
 2\. land firmly in order to obtain a firm contact of the wheels with the runway and immediately land your nose gear,   
 3\. decrease your approach speed,   
 4\. use systematically all the lift dumper devices,   
 5\. land as smoothly as possible,   
 6\. apply maximum braking pressure   
 7\. apply brakes up to antiskid activation

The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:
How does runway slope affect allowable take-off mass, assuming other factors remain constant and not limiting?

options.text: A downhill slope increases allowable take-off mass.
Allowable take-off mass is not affected by runway slope.
An uphill slope increases the allowable take-off mass.
A downhill slope decreases allowable take-off mass.

variant.question: The flight crew of a medium size commercial jet airliner prepares for landing. A local storm just passed through the aerodrome and the runway is now reported as wet and the wind on the landing runway is a 5 kt tailwind. What is the effect of these new conditions on the actual maximum landing mass compared to the planned for a dry runway in still wind conditions?

options.text: The wind and runway conditions will increase the maximum landing mass by increasing the landing distance.
The wind and runway conditions will decrease the maximum landing mass.
The wind and runway surface will NOT affect the maximum landing mass, they only affect the landing distance.
The wind will decrease the maximum landing mass, but the surface condition will increase the maximum landing mass.

variant.question: To minimise the risk of hydroplaning during landing the pilot should:

options.text: use maximum reverse thrust, and should start braking below the hydroplaning speed.
make a “positive” landing and apply maximum reverse thrust and brakes as quickly as possible.
postpone the landing until the risk of hydroplaning no longer exists.
use normal landing-, braking- and reverse technique.

variant.question:
Refer to figure.

The crew of a large jet transport aircraft is planning their departure from Gran Canaria on either runway 21L or 21R, shown in the figure above. After running their performance software, their Maximum Allowed Take-Off Masses are summarised as below.

RWY 21L: 91.4 Tonnes   
 RWY 21R: 90.9 Tonnes

Assuming that the runways have the same slope, what might be the reason for the two different Maximum Allowed Take-Off Masses?

options.text: The runways are climb-limited with the obstacle domains being the same since the runways are close together with parallel thresholds.
More limiting obstacles are within the obstacle domain for runway 21R compared to runway 21L, requiring a greater climb gradient.
Runway 21L has more limiting close-in obstacles than runway 21R and requires a greater climb gradient in the second segment.
The runways are field-length-limited as each runway will have its own individual Field-Length-Limiting Take-Off Mass.
